metadata.title: How to Download Dataset from OpenStreetMap? | by Joe T. Santhanavanich | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to Download Dataset from OpenStreetMap?
metadata.description: There are many available map providers like Google, OS Survey, Mapbox, and several more. But the data is copyrighted and you have to pay for what you use after reaching the limit. While the…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Open Data Commons Open Database License

all_paragraphs: There are many available map providers like Google, OS Survey, Mapbox, and several more. But the data is copyrighted and you have to pay for what you use after reaching the limit. While the OpenStreetMap(OSM) is free for everyone without any hidden costs. It is licensed under the Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL). Everyone can volunteer and contribute the data and everyone can use it for free!

Most of the commercial map providers will not give you access to the data behind the map. With OpenStreetMap, you have full access to the database and you can extract the raw GIS data for the location you need.
Hundreds of thousand contributors all over the world keep updating the data which make OpenStreetMap is one of the most up-to-date GIS databases covering mostly everywhere in the world.

There are several tools online to download GIS or map data from the OpenStreetMap database. Among these tools, you may select them depending on the desired output data format, size, and requested boundary area.

In this case, you can get data directly from the main OpenStreetMap website which is very fast and simple, although the output data format and size are limited. It allows you to export GIS data in .osm format with the area limit of 0.25 degrees (°) squared (e.g. 1°x0.25° or 0.5x0.5° etc), where 1° is approximately 69 miles or 111 km. If you want a bigger size data for your project, please use other available tools.

To extract the data, you just browse to the OpenStreetMap website and use search, pan, zoom tools like any other web map to find an area where you want the data. Then, use the Export tool on the top bar menu and confirm the bounding box region before export the data. That’s it!
If you have the bounding box region saved somewhere, you can also construct the HTTP call directly to the OpenStreetMap API with the following structure to download the OSM data:
Either way, you will get the data of the selected area in .osm format. If you want other data formats, please use other tools.

Now, let’s say you need a bigger data for your project, you may use the BBBike Extract service to extract the GIS data with a specified bounding box region. This web application service allows you to extract and download the OSM data in several formats including OSM, PBF, Garmin, Shapefile, mapsforge, OsmAnd, SVG, GeoJSON, SQL, etc. The maximum request size per request is 512 MB and taking around 2–7 minutes to process.

To use this service, you just have to pan or zoom to the area you want in the map interface and draw the bounding box region of an area you need. Then, you click the extract button and wait for your result which you can see the status of your data extract at https://download.bbbike.org/osm/extract/

If you need the GIS data of any specified administrative area in the world, the GeoFabrik download server would be the right choice for you. It provides ready-made GIS data that update daily and allows you to download data at different levels including continent, country, state, and smaller. The tool provides you the data in .osm format for the entire world and ESRI shapefile format for a small-sized dataset. After you visit the site, you will find a table list of available data at the lower-left corner of the page. You can select to download data from each world-continent in .osm.pbf or .osm.bz2 formats directly.

Or if you need only the specific sub-region, for example, the data in an area of Bayern state of Germany, you can simply select through the sub-region menu Europe > Germany > Bayern. The data on a deeper level will be available to download in both .osm and ESRI shapefile format.
Alternatively, if you want the data in GeoJSON format, you may use OSM Extracts by Interline tool to extract the data in the same approach but it has smaller data coverage.

In case you need a whole OSM dataset for your project and works with the database, feels free to head to Planet OSM service which you can find and download the entire OSM dataset. It is available in a compressed XML file (over 88GB) and a custom PBF format file (over 50GB). You can check a list of tools that used to work with these OSM file types here. Also, a historical OSM dataset is available with this source. More information about the data and network availability from Planet OSM can be found here.

You can take a look at the Overpass API to query parts of the OSM map data you need. The tutorial of how to use the Overpass API is available here. You can try it on the Overpass Turbo as an interface to query OSM data directly through the web.

If you are already working with QGIS software, you may try using the QuickOSM plugin to easily query the specific dataset you need. In the backend, this plugin uses the Overpass API to download the queried OSM data and converts the data into a QGIS vector layer. Assume you already have the updated version of QGIS installed on your machine, let’s have a look at basic guide how to install and use the QuickOSM plugin:
Please note that you can also use any other options to download the GIS data work with QGIS as it supports the OSM vector file by default.

If you are familiar with Python3 or Docker and want to automate some processes for your project, you can use the OpenMapTiles download-osm tool to download the OSM data of specified locations or the entire planet. If you love Java, please check the osmosis repo which is a command-line Java application for processing Open Street Map data.

That’s about it. There are several tools available to extract or download the GIS data from OSM. I hope this article helps you to find the right tool or approach that fits well with your project. Feel free to message me if you have any questions.
